This allows the RBA to introduce the standards on credit cards. These standards are not disallowable instruments and do not require any Government action to implement them. In answer to a question without notice from the honourable Member for Cook on 27 August 2002, I indicated the Government’s support for the RBA’s proposed reforms. (3) The ACCC already has responsibility for ensuring that banks and retailers do not engage in anti-competitive behaviour in setting prices in relation to credit cards. (4) The ACCC already has significant powers to enhance the welfare of Australians through the promotion of competition, as set out in the Trade Practices Act 1974. (5) ASIC already has responsibility for ensuring adequate disclosure of price changes by financial institutions and merchants. Taxation: Bankruptcy Laws (Question No. 1347) Mr Murphy asked the Minister representing the Minister for Revenue and Assistant Treasurer, upon notice, on 3 February 2003: (1) Why is it still lawful to avoid the payment of personal income tax or other tax through the utilisation of bankruptcy or insolvency. (2) Has bankruptcy or insolvency become a business tool to permit individuals to avoid their obligations to pay their fair share of tax. (3) What is the Government doing to change the law to eliminate this rort.
title: Committees

speaker: Mr Costello
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:ing answer to the honourable member’s question: In January 2002, a joint taskforce on the use of bankruptcy and family law schemes to avoid payment of tax issued a report (the taskforce report), making several recommendations to strengthen laws to crack down on high income professionals who try to avoid their tax obligations. On2 May 2003, the Minister for Revenue and Assistant Treasurer, Senator Helen Coonan and Attorney General, Daryl Williams released an update on the implementation of the recommendations from the taskforce report. The Government is currently working on the recommendations that emerged from the taskforce report and together with changes already made to the bankruptcy laws, these initiatives will go a long way to ensuring that high income professionals meet their tax obligations. The recommendations include changes to bankruptcy and family law, a review of taxation offence penalties and measures to address the provision of information by the ATO to third parties. Recent changes to the bankruptcy law, as outlined in a Press Release by the Attorney-General on 5 May 2003, have made it more difficult for people to abuse Australia’s bankruptcy system. These changes prevent people from using bankruptcy in a mischievous or improper way and encourage people to consider alternatives to bankruptcy. The Inspector-General of Bankruptcy also has new powers to investigate the conduct of debt agreement administrators and to set out circumstances in which a person is ineligible to act as a debt agreement administrator. Taxation: Revenues (Question No. 1852) Mr Murphy asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 14 May 2003: (1) Is he able to identify judgments in which the superior Courts of the Commonwealth, States and Territories, have referred to the intentional deprivation of the Commissioner of Taxation of taxes to which the Commissioner was lawfully entitled; if so, what are those reported and unreported judgments. (2) Is he able to say how often the Judiciary has indicated to the Legislative and Executive arms of government and, in particular, the Treasury, in judgments and elsewhere, of the gravity of the intentional deprivation of the Commonwealth of revenues lawfully owed to it; if so, what are those indications and when were they made. (3) Is he aware of the article titled ‘Now companies bulldoze their money around, and give the taxman the bird’ by Elisabeth Sexton in the Sydney Morning Herald dated 28 March 2003, where it was noted that Mr William John Walters (‘Bill the Brickie’), who owned a bricklaying business, faced the NSW Supreme Court for having “presided over 10 company collapses between 1989 and 1998”. (4) What action is being proposed to toughen legislation to prevent multiple, deliberate and systematic repeat offenders seeking to use the existing licit legal instruments and relying on the leniency of the Criminal Justice system to delay for the maximum term the payment of tax liabilities; if no action is being taken, why not. (5) What action is being taken to prevent the perpetuators of repeat company failures from presiding over new companies or holding business licences of all kinds or otherwise prevent them holding directorships or other responsible positions for life; if no action is being taken, why not. (6) Is he able to say whether ten different company collapses presided over by one person over a ten year period constitutes good business management.
title: Questions On Notice

speaker: Mr Costello
theText: The Minister for Revenue and Assistant Treasurer has provided the follow
title: Questions On Notice

speaker: Mr Costello
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:(1) to (2) These cases are available on the public record. (3) to (6) The 2003-04 Commonwealth Budget provides funding for a Corporate Insolvency Initiative, allowing ASIC to increase its level of surveillance, enforcement, and winding-up actions, to prevent corporate abuse. ASIC will receive an additional $12.3 million over the next four years for the initiative. The initiative will involve targeted surveillance of misconduct by officers of small/medium enterprises and high-risk industry sectors identified by ASIC, the Australian Taxation Office, insolvency practitioners and the Cole Royal Commission. The Royal Commission noted the significant efforts by Federal Government agencies to investigate and prevent fraudulent phoenix company activity. The Government has accepted, in principle, the Cole Royal Commission’s key recommendations. As part of its consideration of the report, the Government will consider the recommendations of the Royal Commission that seek to strengthen government actions to detect and eliminate fraudulent phoenix company activity. Further announcements on Government decisions in response to the Royal Commission report will be made in the coming months. Nardell Coal Corporation Pty Ltd (Question No. 2254) Mr Fitzgibbon asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 13 August 2003: (1) Can he confirm that Macquarie Bank had management control in Nardell Coal Corporation that is defaulting on contracts to the value of $43 million. (2) Is the $43 million comprised of (a) $18 million marked to market value of a long-term contract with Macquarie Generation, (b) $10 million relating to a contract for the purchase of a coal preparation plant from Ravensworth, and (c) $15 million owed to contractors. (3) Is he aware that (a) in the case of the Nardell Coal Corporation and its holding company Nardell Holdings, the Macquarie Bank had a shareholder agreement in place that dictated management control and direction, (b) Macquarie Bank always retained a controlling number of Board seats, (c) Board meetings could only be held with a quorum of their appointees present and Macquarie Bank always held a casting vote through the Chairman, Mr Campbell Anderson, who was employed by Macquarie Bank and worked from Macquarie Bank’s offices, (d) Macquarie Bank’s mechanism of funding the operations through a 23% per annum interest-bearing loan ensured that every dollar was only released at a time of their choosing, (e) during the later part of 2002 and early in 2003, Macquarie Bank had directed that every dollar spent required its approval, (f) the other of the Macquarie appointed directors was Mr David Wrench, who was also a Macquarie Bank employee and worked from Macquarie Bank’s premises at Martin Place in Sydney, (g) the remaining two directors were minority shareholders, (h) by agreement, a Macquarie director had to be the Chairman, and the Chairman had a casting vote on the Nardell Board, (i) the Macquarie Bank nominated Director, Mr David Wrench, sent an email from his Macquarie.com email address to Nardell’s managing director on 19 December informing him that a loan from Macquarie Bank would be made to meet monies owed to creditors on the condition that in addition to existing policies and procedures, all material capital expenditure proposals and operating expenditure commitments were to be authorised by Macquarie Direct Investments (MDI), (j) the email referred to a loan being arranged at a 23% interest rate and, until this facility had been documented, the current creditors run for December 2002 could not be met in full, (k) Macquarie Direct Investments is a 100% owned subsidiary of Macquarie Bank Ltd, (l) Nardell was controlled by Bond Street Investments and Macquarie Investment Trust IIIA and Macquarie Investment Trust IIIB, (m) Bond Street Investments Pty Ltd and Macquarie Investment Ltd collectively control Macquarie Investment Trust IIIA and Macquarie Investment Trust IIIA, (o) Bond Street Investments Pty Ltd and Macquarie Investment Ltd are 100% owned subsidiaries of Macquarie Bank Ltd, (p) Mr David Clarke, Macquarie Bank’s Chairman, is a director of Bond Street Investments Pty Ltd, (q) Nardell, upon the authorisation of Macquarie Direct Investment, continued to run up nearly $10 million of debt to creditors during January and February 2003 without any assurances that Macquarie Bank would provide the necessary financial support to meet these obligations, (r) Macquarie Bank knew that Nardell did not have the funds to pay for these purchases, (s) Macquarie Bank did not record a change of risk in their risk management systems (as they are required to do under relevant law) on 20 December 2002 when their $30 million investment changed from an investment in a company that had its primary business risk insured (its currency risk) to an investment in a company which no longer had its primary business risk insured, (t) Macquarie Bank cited the adverse change in the value of the $A exchange rate as one of the 3 reasons for placing Nardell into liquidation, (u) Macquarie Bank instructed Nardell to cease all forward long-term coal sales in late November or early December 2002 thereby exposing Nardell to an adverse movement in US$ coal price, (v) several weeks after receiving an offer by Xstrata to purchase Nardell in early December 2002, Macquarie Bank appointed a so-called “independent” consultant to advise on the viability of Nardell’s mining operation and the independent consultant advised that Nardell be placed into liquidation, (w) when the independent consultant was confronted by the mining inspector to declare his involvement with Xstrata he said that he no longer was employed by them and after enquiries by the mine inspector this was found to be false, (x) the consultant was prior, during and after this consultancy an employee of Xstrata, and (y) when Nardell was placed into liquidation the same independent consultant advised the administrator that he now had a conflict of interest as he was representing Xstrata in the purchase of Nardell’s mining lease. (4) Is it the case that Macquarie Bank Ltd and/or its related companies, whilst publicly professing to attempt to secure the highest price for a liquidated Nardell Coal Corporation, inserted into the Expression of Interest documents a confidentiality clause (clause 3.3) whereby any prospective buyer would not be allowed to discuss any aspect of Nardell with the Minister for Resources or anyone in his department. (5) Can he explain how such a clause could be the public interest and will he ask the relevant regulator to investigate why such a clause was inserted into the sale documents. (6) Will he use his authority under section 14 of the Australian Securities and Investments Commission Act 2001 to direct an investigation into Macquarie Bank’s conduct in managing the Nardell Coal Corporation fiasco. (1) I am not aware of the specific details of transactions and contracts between Macquarie Bank and Nardell Coal Corporation. (2) (a) to (c) I am unaware of the details of the transactions identified. (3) (a) to (y) No. (4) I am unaware of the details of the transaction identified. (5) and (6) I am unaware of the details of the transaction identified. However, I am aware that ASIC is monitoring the liquidation of Nardell Coal Corporation, and that it will be determining whether an investigation into the circumstances of the collapse of Nardell Coal is warranted after consideration of the content of any report lodged with ASIC by the liquidator of Nardell Coal.
title: Questions On Notice
